column4: is there any way to make a deb from a tar.gz source to make installation easier?
usually the contents of a tar.gz consist of a configure script and makefile with source code, not a binary install package
yes that is the kind of tar.gz I mean
usually, just "tar xzf <file> && cd <dir> && configure && make && sudo make install"
yeah. That almost never works. make is always missing something.

that's why is a lot easier to just install from the repositories if you can find it there :)   tracking down dependencies and installing those separately can break your distribution, potentially, if you don't know what the commands do
why doesn't Ubuntu keep their packages up to date? software for dapper is like a year old
well... the next version (Edgy, 6.10) is just about to be released and it has a lot of new stuff
you can upgrade to that
all software I install has bugs fixed in some version like 2 upgrades later but you can't upgrade because Ubuntu doesn't update their packages
are you running dapper? you can do a couple of things, first if you're on dapper, enable the backports repository. or you can just upgrade your whole distro to edgy

well... if you don't want edgy and you need a new version now, you can always just install from source. you say "it never works" but that's not entirely true and you might need to learn a few things, but hatt's always an option
i'm using edgy on my laptop and on a vmware vm on windows with no issues, fyi
you can see that with "apt-cache policy <pkg name>"
not sure about in synaptic
yeah I was wondering in the update manager. It would be nice to see if a particular update is "safe" (from a supported repo) before installing it.

you can instal .debs from anywhere, not just the standards repos
at your own risk, of course
